Comment: My first game with Freddy

I reviewed black's past games and noticed a recent loss with this opening move when his opponent ignored the rook pawn all the way to axb2 followed by bishop capture. I didn't understand much of the game and not sure if the pawn loss was pivotal, but maybe I can do the same thing. I think he's trying to provoke me into something I'll regret. (post game note: plenty of that later)
Wait.... what if he doesn't capture b2 and just sits there? Hold on, that was a recent game, he probably won't do that again. Why didn't I move c4 again?
Wait.... what if he doesn't capture b2 and just sits there? Hold on, that was a recent game, he probably won't do that again. Why didn't I move c4 again?
so I push c3, no apparent resolve to stick to my plan. After I click move, this looks really ugly.
post game note: analysis shows this as an inaccuracy, but I intended on the fianchetto and wanted to castle as soon as possible. Not sure why its an inaccuracy.
post game note: analysis shows this as an inaccuracy, but I intended on the fianchetto and wanted to castle as soon as possible. Not sure why its an inaccuracy.
I don't really know the name of this board configuration, but have seen it a lot. Seems like the d6 blocks in his black bishop. So maybe he's going to fianchetto his bishop.

I don't really know the name of this board configuration, but have seen it a lot. Seems like the d6 blocks in his black bishop. So maybe he's going to fianchetto his bishop.
Since his pawn is on c4, I can hold this pin for a while to make him uncomfortable.
Why not g6 and then Bg7? Seems like this blocks in the queen, but I think he's castling short.
I thought about Nxa4, but thought he would advance on d file. I also didn't want to give up the pinned knight position yet.

I see an opportunity to get his pawns doubled, seems like maybe that will be an advantage. I need every one I can get. Also, I read somewhere that a fianchetto is easy to defeat when the opponent has the queen and bishop with the same color as your fianchetto bishop. I think if I take his bishop with mine, I may be able to defend better. Maybe another advantage.

Not quite sure what to do next. I decide to target the only unprotected piece, c6. I'll move e5 next and take his bishop. Unless I missed something, there's a fork at Qc6 there he'll have to defend.
